Students are not required to purchase any materials for the course, as we will rely upon freely available information sources. But here are some useful resources that you might consult during and after the course.

<br>

## SAFS MS thesis proposals

[Callum Backstrom, Padilla-Gamino Lab](references/example_proposals/backstrom_callum.pdf) - Investigating how thermal bleaching stress affects heavy metal concentrations in the reef-building coral Montipora capitata

[Nicole Doran, Scheuerell Lab](references/example_proposals/doran_nicole.pdf) - Viewing heavy metal contamination of a threatened salmonid through an environmental justice lens

[Karl Veggerby, Scheuerell Lab](references/example_proposals/veggerby_karl.pdf) - Habitat function of shellfish aquaculture ecosystems: Fish behavior and diets


<br>

## SAFS PhD dissertation proposals

[Jeremy Axworthy, Padilla-Gamino Lab](references/example_proposals/axworthy_jeremy.pdf) - The impacts of climate change and microplastics pollution on corals and coral reefs

[Rachel Fricke, Olden Lab](references/example_proposals/fricke_rachel.pdf) - Emerging technologies to assess human benefits from and risks to water resources

[Rachelle Johnson, Olden Lab](references/example_proposals/johnson_rachelle.pdf) - Bioenergetics-based food web assessment of factors limiting production of native salmonids in Upper Skagit River reservoirs

[Helena McMonagle, Essington and Hilborn Labs](references/example_proposals/mcmonagle_helena.pdf) - Quantifying and sustaining ecosystem services of mesopelagic fishes
